13.text:
I got a call that everyone hopes
they never get in their life.

17.text: It was Lisa Clements on the phone.

21.text:
My Department of Correction Director
had been murdered in his own home.

26.text:
Why do I start by
talking to you about Tom?

29.text:
I start because Tom probably taught me
more about civic engagement

33.text:
than any person
I've ever worked with in my life.

37.text:
My first meeting with Tom
was about budget cuts in Colorado,

41.text:
and the need to engage the people
of Colorado in prison closures,

45.text:
and he said, "Rox, we're going to
have to go shut down a community.

50.text:
We're closing a prison
where we're the sole employer,

55.text: and we have to go tell them."

58.text:
So we got in the car
and went to Las Animas, Colorado,

62.text: and we met with the community.

65.text:
People yelled at us,
and they screamed at us.

67.text:
They were terrified, and we escorted out
with security at the end of the meeting.

73.text:
Tom's death had nothing
to do with that night,

76.text:
but it has everything to do
with how we think about good government.

81.text:
We met with that community
every two weeks,

85.text:
and three weeks ago we announced
that we were bringing in new employers,

88.text:
that we had transformed
an old prison facility

92.text:
into a rehabilitation place
for people who are homeless.

96.text: The community will once again have jobs

99.text:
and will once again have
the opportunity to thrive.

109.text:
But in the car,
Tom and I talked a lot about democracy,

113.text:
and open and public dialogue,
and why did we have to close a prison

117.text:
in order to get people
to come out and talk to us?

121.text:
Why is it that free speech
and open elections

124.text:
don't seem to be valued
anymore in America?

127.text:
And at the same time, across the world,
we are losing democracy.

133.text:
Why is it that trust in government
has decreased from 60% just ten years ago

144.text:
What were we going to do about it
as a community,

147.text:
and what were we going to do
about it as taxpayers?

150.text:
Tom and I were people who never wanted
to be in political appointment roles.

155.text:
We were people who just wanted
to improve government,

160.text: what do you do to re-establish trust,

163.text:
and how is it that every one of us
as taxpayers participate in that process?

169.text: We believe that first and foremost,

171.text:
taxpayers have to be seen
not as taxpayers but as customers.

177.text:
Transparency in government
has to become more relevant,

181.text:
and not be, as one of the earlier speaker
referred to it as vomit, but as real data.

186.text: There has to be fiscal accountability.

189.text:
There have to be great leaders
in government.

192.text:
When government does all of that,
it still not going to be trusted,

197.text:
unless we as citizens, we as customers,
become more active.

203.text:
So let's talk about what it means
to be seen as customers.

207.text:
It means that customers, you and I,
are entitled to results.

213.text:
Our public employees must be treated
with respect but so must we, as customers.

220.text:
Bureaucrats should be evaluated
based on how customers are treated.

226.text:
There has to be transparency
in government,

229.text:
and we have to take the time as citizens
to learn about our government functions.

235.text:
We have
the Colorado Information Marketplace

238.text:
and every single strategic plan
for every single department

243.text:
There's no excuses for us
not to know what our government is doing,

250.text:
But we also have a responsibility
as taxpayers to understand

253.text:
exactly where our money is going,
who is getting it,

258.text: We must take the time to learn about it.

262.text:
It is easy to step back and say,
"I'm done with government."

266.text: We can't afford to do that.

268.text:
We see other countries in the world
where that is happening,

272.text:
and it is not the right future
for America.

276.text:
We recently worked hard
to write a book called, "Leadocracy,"

279.text:
that is to encourage
every single person that is in this room

283.text:
to think about
at some point in your career,

287.text:
not just complaining about government,
but stepping up,

291.text:
doing a stent in government,
being a great leader

295.text:
who knows how to analyze,
allocate, and align resources.

299.text:
Figuring out what outcomes
we want in government,

302.text:
and actually stepping forward
and working on it;

305.text:
figuring out
how our government taxes work,

308.text:
when we should be asking for
a tax increase,

311.text: and how we are moving results forward.

314.text:
And results that aren't about
political affiliation, or about a hammer,

319.text:
but results that are about
influencing people

322.text:
to behave in a way
that really makes sense.

325.text:
In government, we also have to have
a sense of urgency,

329.text:
and we as customers have the right
to demand that sense of urgency.

335.text:
"Well, that will take five years to do,
that'll take ten years to do."

339.text:
We as customers have the right
to demand a sense of urgency.

343.text:
We also have the right to demand
that our leaders lean into conflict.

349.text:
What I mean by that is that our leaders
have to do what Tom and I did

353.text:
that night in Las Animas:
go and listen to people.

359.text:
It's easy to talk to the people
that agree with us;

363.text:
it's hard to lean into conflict
and hear from other people.

367.text:
I believe that if government
takes that side of the responsibility,

371.text:
then we as citizens have to take
the other side of the responsibility

374.text: and truly become active in government.

377.text:
We can't sit back and have less than half
of the people in the United States voting.

382.text:
I remember, as a young child,
I was seven years old

385.text:
of one of my first experiences
of civic engagement.

389.text:
My sister and I had some friends
who were with us for the summer.

392.text:
My parents were engaged
in an exchange program in rural Montana.

396.text:
We were all sent downtown
to pick up the mail.

400.text:
We got to the post office,
and we were stopped at the door,

403.text:
and we were told
that we couldn't get the mail.

407.text:
We rode home on our bikes,
we went into the house,

409.text:
and said to our mom
they wouldn't let us get the mail today.

413.text:
My mom said, "Girls, sit down,
you're about to learn a lesson."

418.text:
My mother called
the U.S. Postmaster General,

421.text: and then she called our U.S. Senators,

424.text:
and the next day we were all allowed
back into the Post Office.

428.text:
The issue had been that the two friends
that were with us were African American,

432.text: and they hadn't been allowed in.

435.text:
My mom said, "Never sit back
and watch something unfair happen.

441.text:
Pick up the phone
and do something about it."

453.text:
Later as an adult, I was participating
in my first candidate forum,

457.text:
and I raised my hand and I asked
the candidates who were running for mayor,

462.text:
"What are you going to do
about homelessness

464.text:
and how are you going to help
people to have shelter?"

467.text:
One of the candidates said to me
afterwards, "You know, you can sit back,

472.text:
and you can complain about it,
and you can criticize government.

476.text:
Or if I'm elected, what I would ask you
to do would be to step up

480.text: and try to help end homelessness."

483.text:
When John Hickenlooper was elected Mayor,
I became the Chair of Denver's Road Home,

489.text:
and have [helped] his efforts
to end homelessness.

491.text:
That's how I ended up in public service,
because I got involved.

495.text: I had something to say and a bureaucrat,

498.text:
as somebody who was becoming
an elected official said,

502.text: "Step up and help, don't just sit back."

506.text:
So I ask you all today to think about
how you all can step up.

509.text:
Throughout Colorado we have
active conversations happening

514.text:
on a myriad of issues from red tape
to education to healthcare.

519.text: Recently the Governor even called for

521.text:
a conversation to happen
throughout the state on death penalty,

525.text:
which I have to say, I've ended up
in more conversations

527.text:
about having conversations
about having a conversation

532.text:
But out of it, it really is: are we
willing to step forward and be engaged?

537.text: There's a non-profit called TBD Colorado

540.text:
that has been reaching out
across the state in online surveys

544.text:
in community focus groups
and educational forums

547.text:
asking the citizens of Colorado
to help us determine

551.text:
our future in education,
and transportation, and healthcare.

556.text:
We've had an amazing response
from the people of Colorado,

560.text:
and last year, it changed policy
in our state house and senate.

566.text:
We have 64 young people across the state
of Colorado who have engaged

571.text:
with our marketing experts
and our business leadership,

575.text:
and we've had over 200 people submit
online videos about branding Colorado,

580.text:
and what makes Colorado
a great state to live in and be in.

586.text:
We invite you to be part
of that community conversation.

590.text:
Make a difference
in terms of who we are as a state.

594.text:
In every community across Colorado
there are business groups

598.text:
who are leading an effort to create
economic development in their communities.

603.text:
In the front range,
many of those conversations

605.text:
are about how we recruit
businesses to Colorado,

609.text: how we engage in large-scale growth.

612.text:
But if you were in conversations
in Craig or in Steamboat,

615.text:
the conversation is about how
we recruit people working from home,

619.text: how we get to the individual entrepreneur,

625.text:
is our unemployment rate is going down
because citizens are engaged.

630.text: We have engaged in the conversation,

632.text:
and we are saying that we are not going to
turn away and let democracy go away.

640.text: In 1910, Gifford Pinchot said what is,

644.text:
for me, one of the most important mantras
that I keep on my wall.

648.text:
He said, "It is a far greater thing
to be a good citizen

652.text:
than to be a good Republican
or a good Democrat."

664.text:
When we think about what it means
to be a good citizen,

669.text:
it means holding
our government accountable,

672.text:
it means stepping forward,
it means being engaged,
